children.text: The purpose of this Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is to outline the process for planning, conducting, reporting, and following up on internal audits within [Company Name]. This process ensures compliance with [relevant standards, e.g., company policies, industry regulations, quality management system requirements], identifies opportunities for process improvement, and prepares the organization for external assessments.

This SOP applies to all [Company Name] personnel involved in or subject to internal audits. It encompasses all [relevant company activities/areas, e.g., operational processes, departments, facilities, systems] that fall under the scope of the internal audit program.
[Overall Program Oversight Role, e.g., Head of Quality, Senior Management]
Oversees the overall internal audit program, ensures adequate resources, and reviews significant audit outcomes.
[Audit Program Coordinator Role, e.g., Quality Assurance Manager, Internal Audit Lead]
Coordinates the internal audit process, develops and maintains the audit schedule, ensures auditor competence, reviews audit reports, and tracks corrective actions.
Conduct audits in compliance with this SOP, objectively document findings, and provide feedback to audited personnel.
Cooperate with the audit team, provide requested documentation and access, and implement corrective actions as required.
Internal Audit: A systematic, independent, and documented process for obtaining audit evidence and evaluating it objectively to determine the extent to which audit criteria are fulfilled.
Audit Criteria: A set of policies, procedures, or requirements against which audit evidence is compared.
Non-Conformance (NC): A deviation from a specified requirement, policy, procedure, or standard.
Observation: A statement of fact made during an audit, which may indicate a potential area for improvement or a minor deviation not classified as a non-conformance.
Corrective Action: Action to eliminate the cause of a detected non-conformance or other undesirable situation.
Audit Report: A formal document summarizing the audit process, findings, and conclusions.
Develop an annual audit plan covering all [relevant company activities/areas]. The plan should be [risk-based, e.g., high-risk areas audited more frequently].

Determine audit frequency based on factors such as [regulatory requirements, historical performance, process criticality, changes in processes or systems]. Include additional ad-hoc audits as needed (e.g., for new processes, after significant changes, in response to specific incidents).
Appoint qualified internal auditors who are independent of the area being audited to ensure objectivity.
Ensure auditors possess the necessary knowledge of [relevant standards/regulations/processes] and auditing techniques. [Specify training requirements, e.g., internal auditor training course].

Major Non-Conformance: [Define criteria, e.g., systemic deviation, significant impact on quality/compliance, or potential for regulatory non-compliance].

Schedule a follow-up audit or specific verification activities for [e.g., all major and critical findings, or based on risk] to confirm effective implementation of corrective actions.
Retain all audit-related documents for a minimum of [specific timeframe, e.g., five years, or as required by regulatory standards/company policy].
Store records securely and ensure they are readily accessible for review.
10. Monitoring and Review of the Audit Program
Conduct an annual review of the overall internal audit program to assess its effectiveness, efficiency, and continued suitability.
Adjust audit frequencies, checklists, procedures, and auditor training as needed based on audit results, changing risks, and organizational changes.
[Specific Role, e.g., QA Manager/Internal Audit Lead] Review: Periodically review the entire audit program, focusing on trends in non-conformances, recurring issues, and overall compliance status.

All personnel assigned as internal auditors must undergo initial training on audit procedures, [e.g., relevant standards, risk assessment, interviewing techniques, documentation standards, handling non-conformances], and the proper use of all associated audit forms/documents.

Conduct refresher training for auditors at least [specific frequency, e.g., annually, biennially] to ensure they remain updated on best practices, regulatory changes, program updates, and any revisions to the audit forms/documents.
